Created an attachment (id=53186) the sample design flie
I find it is caused by DTE's checkin "ResultClass.java".

It's reproduced on 2.2.0 build 1107
thanks,

When Data is saving ResultClass information, it will compare the column names used by column binding to the column names in ResultClass. However, this is not enough for column alias can also be used in column binding. Add code to compare column alias as well when save the ResultClass information, this bug is so that fixed.
Verified and close

bug.short_desc: new xml wizard: create from xml template always uses xml template

long_desc.thetext:
using wtp2.0 M3-sdk-200611021324
1. create new xml -> create xml file from an xml template 2. in "select xml template" "use xml template" checkbox is off by default 3. hit finish 4. xml file is still created using "xml declaration" template (I expected a blank file)
Also, "Use XML Template" should probably be checked by default.
The fix for this bug is included in the fix for bug 116315.
verified in wtp2.0 M5 sdk 200702210538

bug.short_desc: Launch config dialog should skip private configs when checking for name duplication

long_desc.thetext:
Steps to reproduce:
1. Create some shared launch configuration with "org.eclipse.debug.ui.private" attribute set to true. Let's name it, say, "My launch"
2. Go to Launch Configurations dialog and try to create a configuration with the same name "My launch". The dialog will not allow to do this even if the physical location of the launch config file is different from the config created on the first step.
The problem is that the code for the name verification just checks whether a launch config with such name exists, and sets an error message if it does. It should do something more flexible to handle private configs correctly. For example, check for name duplication excluding private configs first, then check for config file location conflict.

The problem is that the underlying launch config namespace is flat.
*** This bug has been marked as a duplicate of 59289 ***

But as it's pointed in the bug 59289, there are situations (and this is my case, in fact) when the physical locations of the configurations are not the same and it is safe to save it with the same name as some private configuration.
Let me explain my use case more. I have a launch configuration of some type which can be launched for different projects. When a configuration is launched for a project, I duplicate the configuration file with org.eclipse.debug.ui.private attribute set in the project - let's say in ${project}/configuration/${launch_name}.launch file. I do it to be able to find out what configuration was used last time for this project and to be able to repeat the original launch.
And the problem is that after that LCD doesn't allow user to name a new configuration with a name which exists somewhere inside of my project. This just doesn't seem logical to me.
Does it seem to be a reasonable use case?
Yes, however the underlying infrastructure still needs to be enhanced to understand/leverate this (and it's all part of the same problem).

The reason is because we can't find WORKSPACE_CLASSPATH_KEY when load the class. And the value is set in plugin org.eclipse.birt.report.debug.ui. But org.eclipse.birt.report.debug.ui.jar is not loaded when start 2.1.2 all-in-one.
Reasign to GUI team to deep research.
The WORKSPACE_CLASSPATH_KEY key need set by viewer. That's a run time parameter instead of debug time parameter. On the other word, BIRT script sitll can run withou debug plugin.
Switch to package with Eclipse 3.2.1 Relase Build
closed!

bug.short_desc: [JUnit] Compare Actual with Expected Test Result

long_desc.thetext:
Unfortunately, this can't be fixed without changes to the JUnit library. For String comparisons with Assert#assertEquals(String, String), a ComparisonFailure exception is thrown which contains the expected and the actual strings. For all other kinds of Assert#assertEquals(*, *), an AssertionFailedError is thrown, which only contains a failure message but not the compared objects.
What you could to is to write your own assertEquals method that throws a ComparisonFailure.

Fixed.
In ReportDocumentReader, incorrect behavior as following caused the bug: generateBy of TableBandContent of group header/footer are set to the TableBandDesign of group footer/header. So, for any group which has header and no footer, or has footer and no header, the TableBandContent of group header or footer has no generateBy.
To verify: 1. create a report 2. create a table, bind to a dataset 3. create a group in the table, make sure there are some data items in the group header, delete the group footer. 4. create another table, bind to a dataset. create a group in the table, make sure there are some data items in the group footer, delete the group header. 5. Run the report using web viewer. Expected result: report can be rendered without error.
Verified and closed

bug.short_desc: [launcher] -noExit argument doesn't work while deploy OSGi application with Java Web Start

long_desc.thetext:
I'm trying deploy an OSGi application with Java Web Start. I have no application defined, so I set eclipse.ignoreApp=true. I want to keep the OSGi application running, so I pass -noExit argument to the WebStartMain.class. The following is the snippet.
<application-desc main-class="org.eclipse.core.launcher.WebStartMain"> <argument>-nosplash</argument> <argument>-noExit</argument> </application-desc>
<resources> <!-- Reference to the startup.jar. This does not change --> <jar href="startup.jar"/>
<property name="eclipse.ignoreApp" value="true"/> ......
The problem is the application is terminated after OSGi framework is started, which means the -noExit argument doesn't work. The cause is since there is no defined eclipse application running (because eclipse.ignoreApp=true) so EclipseStarter.run(String[] args, Runnable endSplashHandler) will return very fast. The OSGi Framework will still be active (because osgi.noShudown=true). But in this case control of the main thread is given back to WebStartMain which calls System.exit(result).
Java web start is a way of Java application deployment. An application should have the same behavior under different ways of deployment. So I think WebStartMain should check osgi.noShutdown property before it call System.exit(result).
We should investigate that as part of the uniformisation of the startup code.
This is still an issue in the new launcher. The fix is simple, I will add a patch.

Created an attachment (id=62535) patch
Patch that does the same check in WebStartMain.main as Main.main does for the osgi.noShutdown flag.
patch released to HEAD

font: 11px/18px Verdana, Arial;
When I format the document this changes to:

Also, if I have a line in the CSS source such as:
padding: 0px; *padding: 5px; /*the * is so IE only uses it and is ignored by FF*/
This becomes:
padding: 0px; * padding: 5px; /*the * is so IE only uses it and is ignored by FF*/
The * is moved upto the line above.

bug.short_desc: [Viewers] Take over SWT programming pattern to JFace Viewers

long_desc.thetext: To open ColumnViewer for reusablility we should not make it final making the constructor protected forces people to subclass it and not directly creating instances from it.
Created an attachment (id=53191) patch to make ViewerColumn more resuable

Created an attachment (id=53853) patch to provide make JFace behave nearly identical to SWT
This addresses various things: - passing of JFace Viewer instance on creation (ViewerColumn) - removing of passing LabelProvider using the constructor (ViewerColumn) - make viewer column non final but forcing to subclass by declaring constructor as protected - provide implementations for TableViewerColumn, TreeViewerColumn which are final and can not be subclassed
A thing we might consider to avoid NLP all over the place is to check for null in label provider and editing support which is not done currently I think everywhere.
A thing I'm uncertain about is how to deal with the listeners which need to be attached to the ViewerColumn Boris mentionned today. Boris do you mean that any time a ViewerColumn#setLabelProvider() is called the event should be triggered?

No, whenever the label provider is set, the ViewerColumn should attach itself as a listener. See ContentViewer. Whenever a LabelProviderChangeEvent is received, it should call handleLabelProviderChanged() on its viewer.
Created an attachment (id=53860) Reworked to include listeners

Created an attachment (id=54004) Patch that applies to HEAD
It tries to make subclassing harder by using the same style like SWT does instead of declaring something final!

Some comments
We don't need the checkSubclass method - we can either specify it is not to be subclassed in the constructor or make in final.
If we do with Table and Tree column provider there is no need. Tom do you see a column based on say a Nebula grid being created? If so then we may need to leave this open.

bug.short_desc: DeferredUpdateManager should not use Display.getCurrent()

long_desc.thetext: GEF and draw2d are not thread safe. Therefore, you can not access your editparts or figures from multiple threads. If you could do this, you will end up with ArrayIndexOutOfBounds and other exceptions. You must use syncExec or asyncExec to access your editparts from the appropriate thread.
Is this the only issue you are having with this use case? Display.getCurrent() is null?

The use case is: I started programming a kind of UML Editor and wanted to syncronize with the jdt. The reconciler, which fires the code change events works in a different thread and so my listener refreshs the editparts in the same thread.
After using Display.syncExec I had no other problems.
I just wondered why I have to start a new thread only to allow draw2d to start another thread.

If you refresh your editparts in one thread, and the Main thread is in the middle of editing the model, painting, laying out, performing hit-testing for the mouse, or many other things which involve reading or writing the figures, you will have subtle threading issues. Debugging the NPE you saw is much easier than tracking down thread-related bugs.
JDT has to do the same thing when they respond to these notifications. If they are updating an SWT tree, they use (a)syncExec.

bug.short_desc: Exception when server goes offline.

long_desc.thetext:
Currently when the server goes offline methods throw runtime exception java.lang.reflect.UndeclaredThrowableException, caused by: org.eclipse.corona.soa.client.SOAClientException, caused by: java.net.ConnectException.
The runtime exception isn't declared and it isn't meaningful. Loosing connection to server is rather a typical situation and proxy methods should declare such exception. In general we need to handle exceptions in connection to server.
Due to no exceptions declared, they are not handled at all. One of the implications it causes is that you cannot close Eclipse when server goes offline and you have at least one project container opened. You need to either kill Eclipse or restore the server.
I think it is rather to big issue to still handle it in M5, but it should definitely be resolved in M7.

(In reply to comment #0) > Currently when the server goes offline methods throw runtime exception [...]
Of course I mean ProjectContainerProxy methods.

Proposal: 1) all PCP methods throws CoronaException. 2) new Factory/Translator class which converts *known* server exceptions to specific CoronaExceptions (like java.net.ConnectException to CoronaConnectionException which extends CoronaException). 3a) all calls to projectContainerManager within PCP should be surrounded with try catch (Throwable) block, in catch block translator from point 2 is used to convert exception. 3b) at the end of RPCProxyHandler.invoke where currently SOAClientException is created we can use the Translator from point 2 to convert exception to corona exception (in this approach no surround with try catch block is required within PCP)
What do you think of this?
I think this bug needs to be reviewed. I think someone should look at fixing this from the ContextContainerManagerProxy. Piotr or I would be an excellent choice but I won't get to it for a while.

bug.short_desc: ClassifierImpl#isRedefinitionContextValid never returns TRUE

long_desc.thetext: ClassifierImpl#isRedefinitionContextValid never returns TRUE if the Classifier is owned by a Package. If this is going to be fixed by allowing two Classifiers owned by a Package to redefine one the other without having a Generalization relationship between them, then please make sure that StateMachine redefinition validation still requires Generalization. Currently StateMachine redefinition validation code does not check that, but rather relies on Classifier to make the check.
This is really a problem with the way redefinition contexts are being validated for state machines - a generalization between the contexts should be required rather than a generalization.
The fix has been committed to CVS.
The fix is available in build M200611162216.

bug.short_desc: Redefinition should be treated as a transitive relationship in validation code

long_desc.thetext: If B2 redefines B1 in context of A2 then validation will check that the context of B2 (A2) redefines the context of B1 (A1). Validation will pass if A2 directly redefines A1. Validation will fail if A2 only indirectly redefines A1, as in "A2 redefines X and X redefines A1". This should not be the case. Redefinition should be thought of as a transitive relationship and "A2 redefines X and X redefines A1" should also mean "A2 redefines A1" and the validation should pass.
Only the constraints for state machines, regions, and states do this kind of "recursive" checking for redefinitions.
Classifiers too! :-)
The fix has been committed to CVS.
The fix is available in build M200611301201.

bug.short_desc: [web services] WebServicesManager regression, gets out of synch

long_desc.thetext:
There were performance improvements made to keep the WebServicesManager from eating too much memory. It used to have an open edit model on every project in the workspace. This has been corrected. However, now the notifications to update the manager are not working properly. We used to rely on edit model changed events for additions of webservice.xml or webservicesclient.xml files. Since we will no longer have an edit model on a non web service project, when these files are created we will not get this edit model changed event. So, we already have cases for .wsdl and .wsil in the resource change listener code, and we just need to add cases for the webservices.xml and webservicesclient.xml.
A hacky workaround for now is to have the web service generator copy the wsdl or wsil file last, after creating webservices.xml or webservicesclient.xml.
And for the user, workaround is to close and reopen the project.
Created an attachment (id=53233) Proposed patch

The fix is straightforward. Expand our web service resource change listener to listen for webservice.xml and webserviceclient.xml as well as .wsdl and .wsil files. Then, force a refresh on the navigator by notifying the web service synchronization updater. Patch is attached for review.
approve
This is released for the maintenance and head streams.
verified
Verified

bug.short_desc: GMF generated code some types when initializing diagram file from model file

long_desc.thetext:
The GMF generated diagram code omits certain types (possibly because they are derived from other types) when creating a diagram file from the model file (i.e. via right-click on the model and selecting "initialize <model> diagram file").
Steps to reproduce: 1.) unzip the attached proect directory and import the project 2.) build genmodel, create EMF code 3.) create model generator and create diagram code 4.) fix the two compile errors by changing the two offending "getFigureArtifactNameFigure()" method calls to read "getFigureArtifactContainerNameFigure()" (note the "Container"). (I already file a bug for this...). 5.) launch the generated application (.launch file is included) 6.) unzip the "GMF_example_leonardo2.zip" file 7.) import the example project into the runtime workbench 8.) select the file default.leonardo2 and issue the context command "initialize leonardo2_diagram diagram file"
The diagram will look like in the first screenshot attached, but the model actually contained an additional node of type "ArtifactContainerType" which has silently been dropped. The diagram *should* look like in the second screenshot attached.
Michael
Created an attachment (id=53201) the project to create the application
Created an attachment (id=53202) the example diagram file
Created an attachment (id=53204) screenshot after initialization of diagram file
Created an attachment (id=53205) This is how the diagram SHOULD look like (also the diagram used to generate the model file)
Perhaps, 2.0.1?

You have two meta-classes: - ArtifactType - ArtifactContainerType extends ArtifactType
in your meta-model. The problem is: it is unslear which diagram node should be created by GMF for ArtifactContainerType. To resolve this ambiguity you have to add an OCL constraint to the NodeMapping for ArtifactType:
not oclIsKindOf(leonardo2::ArtifactContainerType)
As a result diagra initialization code strarts working properly.

attachment.desc: the project to create the application
screenshot after initialization of diagram file
This is how the diagram SHOULD look like (also the diagram used to generate the model file)

bug.short_desc: quick search on the remote repository

long_desc.thetext:
With existing repository providers for Bugzilla, Trac and Jira it should be possible to create a default query against all registered task repositories. Such queries could use text from the "Find" field as a basic quick search term. Those queries could be run in a background and results perhaps should be shown in a separate virtual "Quick Find" category that will be populated lazily.
Other option. Instead of showing results in Task List, kick such query into the Search view (i.e. if user hit Ctrl-Enter in the "Find" field).
So, to support this we'll need some kind of API to get the query instance for basic "quick find" from each repository provider type.
Mik, the whole point for this is to be able to kick a global repository search without going trough query dialog
Will consider as part of improving the search story for 3.0.

bug.short_desc: [Field Assist] - API - Deprecate DecoratedField and related classes

long_desc.thetext: If ControlDecoration is adopted in replacement of DecoratedField by all existing SDK clients, then we should deprecate DecoratedField.

Deprecating DecoratedField includes deprecating these classes:
DecoratedField IControlCreator TextControlCreator
If we remove Field Decoration from the ControlDecoration API, it also involves deprecating: FieldDecoration FieldDecorationRegistry Note: The registry should continue to register the decorations declared in 3.2, for compatibility. However, the declaration of the overlay images (error, warning, content assist, error with quickfix) should be done somewhere else and those image ID's should be made public, so that clients can access the images by ID. Currently the image ID's are declared privately in the registry and only the decorations are available.
We should also deprecate independent classes involved in the old visual design: FieldAssistColors
We could REMOVE ComboControlCreator (it was just added in 3.3 M1 so it could be deprecated temporarily and removed before 3.3 ships)
Finally, the field assist example should be updated: - remove the DecoratedFieldTestDialog and collapse ControlDecorationTestDialog into FieldAssistTestDialog - remove the preference for switching between DecoratedField and ControlDecoration - remove the preferences and code for showing colors on errors and required fields - remove the preferences and code for required field decorations
One more... would need to deprecate ContentAssistField (in org.eclipse.ui.fieldassist)
*** Bug 163275 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. ***
*** Bug 163278 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. ***

reassigning to Kevin to watch over this one...
If we deprecate these, it would be nice to supply patches to known clients: -FindReplaceDialog -ImageAndMessageArea (perhaps we could just deprecate this class anyway, since the animated tray is no longer used)

> If we remove Field Decoration from the ControlDecoration API, it also involves > deprecating: > FieldDecoration > FieldDecorationRegistry
...
Is deprecation of FieldDecoration and FieldDecorationRegistry necessary? These are more like generic concepts (FieldDecoration = an Image + a Description). Right now in my code FieldDecoration acts as an intermediary so that I can support both DecoratedField and ControlDecoration and whatever comes in future that understands the decoration concept.
It's not absolutely necessary, and getting this kind of feedback will help us decide what to do.

Kevin, we need to sort this out for M6. Do you want me to take ownership of this bug? Right now we are in no-man's land, as there is no public access to the error/quick fix decoration.
The minimal change we should make is to add a public field to access the error/quick fix decoration from the registry and not deprecate anything.

Transfering ownership to Susan. Agree should provide access to error/quickfix from registry. I don't mind us providing something to pair image+description but maybe DecoratedField is the wrong name now (and confusing vis-a-vis ControlDecoration).

cc'ing Dani for comment as he is affected by deprecation of ContentAssistField.
I think the best strategy would be the following:
(1) - deprecate DecoratedField and related classes since we will not be supporting enhancements to this code and will be encouraging clients to use ControlDecoration instead. The classes to be deprecated are: DecoratedField IControlCreator TextControlCreator ContentAssistField ComboControlCreator (will be temporarily deprecated and then removed, since it was added in 3.3 M1). Provide a patch to platform text FindReplace dialog to use ControlDecoration
(2) - deprecate FieldAssistColors since it encourages allocation of colors to show error and required fields. It seems a bit odd to change API as visual design ideas change, but the fact that use of color for fields was exposed as API is unfortunate. The intent is that any future API would be more general (pass a control, and some helper does the right thing to it) rather than exposing particular ideas such as colors in the API itself.
(3) - leave the FieldDecorationRegistry and FieldDecoration API as is since clients have found it to be a convenience, but do not add any new decorator ID's for 3.3 since the new graphics (such as error+quick fix) aren't used in the SDK. The rationale is that we prematurely introduced API for graphics in 3.2, such as the required field decoration, and do not want to do so again.
Comments?
cc'ing Dejan for comment since he is a heavy decorator user.

>If ControlDecoration is adopted in replacement of DecoratedField by all >existing SDK clients, then we should deprecate DecoratedField. Mmh - I tend to disagree with this because it is by far not adopted yet. Simply take a look at clients that still use the Platform Text story due to lack of a good solution. For a quick list in the SDK look at those still referring to org.eclipse.ui.contentassist.ContentAssistHandler.
If you plan to pull out the ComboControlCreator I'd be thankful to see a patch that results in the same layout of the dialog as it is now.
I agree with Dani. Check the usage in org.eclipse.ui.forms and if you deprecate something we are using, supply alternative or instructions on how to get rid of the deprecation warnings.

I think you might be misunderstanding the proposal. We have two solutions in Platform UI field assist for decorating fields, DecoratedField and ControlDecoration. Neither is widely adopted yet in the SDK, but we'd like to deprecate one of them to make clear the direction going forward.
The desire is to deprecate DecoratedField, which is only used by the FindReplaceDialog. UI Forms uses ControlDecoration (and was one driving force in forming requirements for ControlDecoration, since DecoratedField was too confining).
Platform Text currently uses ControlDecoration in its implementation of the content assist cue provider. (AbstractControlContentAssistSubjectAdapter).
It is not critical that we deprecate DecoratedField, but it is confusing to new adopters that there are two choices, and we don't intend to add features to DecoratedField.

Tod - any thoughts? Another way to discourage use of DecoratedField would be to remove its use in the example dialog, but leave it around for another release to gather more data on its usage vs. ControlDecoration.
Just to clarify: moving the FindReplaceDialog back to use control decoration as it used to is fine with me.

My feeling is also that we should deprecate - one of the most common complaints from people using our code is that there are two ways to do things and they have no clear guidance.
It will also allow us to make a thinner workbench plug-in when we move the deprecated code to a compatibility plug-in.

Dani - I think we are still not on the same page. FindReplaceDialog never used ControlDecoration. In 3.2 we moved it from platform text content assist to DecoratedField. The proposal is to now move it to ControlDecoration so that there are no longer SDK users of DecoratedField, and we can deprecate DecoratedField.
I know. I was not referring to the exact class but the mechanism we used in Platform Text.

Created an attachment (id=60755) patch for field assist and findreplace dialog
Dani - here is the proposed patch to find/replace dialog. The patch includes the changes to field assist since a new method in ContentAssistCommandAdapter is required. Note that the underlying code providing the content assist behavior is identical...the only change is the class used to render the decoration.

API REQUEST: Deprecate DecoratedField and related classes, and add one method to org.eclipse.ui.fieldassist.ContentAssistCommandAdapter
RATIONALE: During 3.3, we introduced ControlDecoration to deal with lifecycle and layout issues introduced by DecoratedField. Clients (most prominently UI Forms) who previously could not use DecoratedField have successfully migrated to ControlDecoration. We would like to deprecate the old classes to make it clear what clients should be using. In addition, we would like to deprecate FieldAssistColors which supports a visual design no longer endorsed by the visual design team.
SPECIFICS: Deprecate these JFace classes: - DecoratedField - IControlCreator - TextControlCreator - ComboControlCreator (and eventually remove this one as it is new to 3.3) - FieldAssistColors
Deprecate this workbench class: - ContentAssistField
Add API to org.eclipse.ui.fieldassist.ContentAssistCommandAdapter to provide access to the workbench content assist image and the proper key-binding specific text (previously available in ContentAssistField) /** * Return the field decoration that should be used to indicate that content * assist is available for a field. Ensure that the decoration text includes * the correct key binding text. * * @return the {@link FieldDecoration} that should be used to show content * assist. * @since 3.3 */ public FieldDecoration getContentAssistFieldDecoration()
PERFORMANCE IMPACTS: None
RISKS: Clients have a short migration time to avoid deprecation warnings. Conversion patches will be provided to SDK clients (FindReplaceDialog is the only known client)
I looked at the patch and what I don't like is that much more code is needed on the client side than before. Can't this be hidden from the client as the old solution does?
+1 to adding deprecations

Dani - I understand your point. The challenge is balancing any newly introduced convenience API with tying it to closely to the decoration implementation. We had to deprecate ContentAssistField because it exposed too much detail of DecoratedField.
However, I've tried several alternatives, and I think I have a better solution, which is to introduce a new constructor on ContentAssistCommandAdapter. This constructor has a boolean parameter that instructs the adapter to create the decoration. This was not possible before when DecoratedField had to create the control. In this way, you can get the decorator "for free" without the API bleeding so much detail of implementation, and the adapter will set up the decoration using whatever the best practices are of the visual design.
Please see the new patch.
Kevin - could you please review also before I propose the new API? Note that so far the PMC has only approved the deprecations, but not any new convenience API to replace ContentAssistField. We can't deprecate until we provide enough information for the client to decorate, or in this proposal, default decoration behavior. Note that the old constructor will default to NOT decorating the control, since it never did before.
I'd like Dani and Kevin to comment before asking PMC to revisit.
Created an attachment (id=60835) patch with new constructor on ContentAssistCommand adapter and alternate Find/Replace code

+1
I agree the Susan/Tod that the deprecations are required to make programming model clear.
Adding convenience to ContentAssistCommandAdapter seems reasonable: before it had behavioural responsibility in munging a control to support content assist (add listeners etc), now it applies the visual cues too. Actually I like this model.
+1 for the new patch.

The deprecations are approved, but let me be clear that to deprecate ContentAssistField, we need to add this API to ContentAssistCommandAdapter. See discussion why in comment #24 and comment #26. McQ, can you please also approve the new API? It is a new constructor to ContentAssistCommandAdapter which has a boolean parameter specifying whether to provide the content assist decoration: /** * Construct a content proposal adapter that can assist the user with * choosing content for the field. * * @param control * the control for which the adapter is providing content assist. * May not be null. * @param controlContentAdapter * the IControlContentAdapter used to obtain and * update the control's contents as proposals are accepted. May * not be null. * @param proposalProvider * the IContentProposalProvider used to obtain * content proposals for this control, or null if * no content proposal is available. * @param commandId * the String id of the command that will invoke the content * assistant. If not supplied, the default value will be * "org.eclipse.ui.edit.text.contentAssist.proposals". * @param autoActivationCharacters * An array of characters that trigger auto-activation of content * proposal. If specified, these characters will trigger * auto-activation of the proposal popup, regardless of the * specified command id. * @param installDecoration * A boolean that specifies whether a content assist control * decoration should be installed. The client is responsible for * ensuring that adequate space is reserved for the decoration. * Clients that want more fine-grained control of the * decoration's location or appearance should use * false for this parameter, creating their own * {@link ControlDecoration} and managing it directly. * @since 3.3 */ RISKS: None. The original constructor defaults to the old behavior of providing no decoration. PERFORMANCE IMPACT: None. The same mechanism to provide decorations will be used whether this API is introduced or not. This is protocol that allows clients to get content assist behavior and decoration with one call. The only reason we COULDN'T collapse this behavior into ContentAssistCommandAdapter last release was that the decoration had to create the control, so it couldn't be decorated from the adapter.

Fixed >20070315.
Opened Platform Text bug #177630 for migrating FindReplaceDialog and included latest patch. Opened Platform UI bug #177633 for removing the experimental class ComboControlCreator once FindReplaceDialog is migrated.

bug.short_desc: [clean up] Clean up doesn't follow formatter options

long_desc.thetext:
3.3 M3
I enabled Clean up on save, and used the default save participant profile. When I started using it, I noticed that it was formatting my comments, even though my active formatter profile says comments should not be formatted. When I investigated I noticed that the clean up profile has a separate check box for "format comments". Why have a separate option for this when it is already part of the general formatter profile? The expected behaviour is that my formatter settings will always be obeyed...
Not related to clean up on save but a general "clean up" issue.
the request makes sense, I guess it's better to reuse the settings as specified in the formatter profile.

Ok, I can do that. But remember, that the formatter settings do not allow to specify which kind of comment to format (See Bug 49412). On clean up you can turn on/off formatting of Javadoc, single line, and multi line comments. I think formatting javadoc on safe makes sense, formatting single line comments certainly not. I think fixing Bug 49412 first would make more sense and init the clean up comment formatting setting with the formatter setting in the meantime.

Fixing bug 49412 makes sense... then you on the clean up wizard you just need a "Format code" checkbox, and get rid of the comment formatting checkboxes. (or have a combo that alway me to select a formatter profile to use for this particular cleanup, if you want different formatter settings for cleanup from regular format command)
This doesn't look like a Vista specific issue

bug.short_desc: [assist] code assist doesn't correctly use scanner eofPosition

long_desc.thetext:
Completion engine use the fact that the scanner doesn't really stop to scan at Scanner.eofPosition.
If completion is inside a method body then completion engine intialize the scanner eofPostion at the location the completion. But it use the fact that the scanner will scan util the end of the current token. e.g. fo|o = null; the eofPosition will be at | but the scanner will scan until the end of foo. The completion engine use this position as the end of the completion token.
This can be considered as a non correct use and a fix to bug 161400 will change this property of the scanner. Completion process should be adapted to support the fix of 161400.
Both fixes should be released at the same time.
Released for 3.3M4. David, I released since I released the code for bug 161400.
Verified for 3.3M4 with I20061211-1119

Hello Eugene,
Attached the patch to fix the problems described here.
Patch is added to export and import the 'Import Filter Definitions' while exporting and importing the the log sets. If filter already exists while import of logsets , old filter definition will be replaced by new filter definition.
Modules: org.eclipse.tptp.monitoring.logui org.eclipse.tptp.platform.common.ui
Please review the patch and let me know if you have any further changes.
Created an attachment (id=64924) Patch for the problems described in this defect is attached.

I reviewed the patch and have a few concerns here:
1). I see you reuse the FilterResourceFileHandler to save and load the query model. This results in a 'hybrid' log set file, where log file elements and filter queries are in totally different models. The resulting log set file looks a bit weird.
2). Step 1 is a quick fix for the problem. A more proper approach would be to either (A) move log file element to EMF model and persist with EMF resource, or (B) have a DTD mapping for the existing query model. Neither of them are not simple changes and risky to be contain by 4.4 release. The current workaround of the problem is to export filter and export log set in 2 different steps and also import the 2 files in 2 different steps. It's not user-friendly but I don't think it's a good idea to have a weird logset file which looks very unprofessional.
Eric, Dave. Since the suggested changes (A or B) in 2) above takes longer time to be implements and the impact is big on the import log wizard structure, I suggest to push this out from 4.4, and have a more formal change in the code base to instead. Please advise.
Created an attachment (id=64947) sample logset file with the patch
I have also taken a look over the patch and I agree that this is not a solution we want to go with. Until we have a complete solution for this issue I would say we shouldn't commit the changes.

(In reply to comment #11) > I reviewed the patch and have a few concerns here: > > 1). I see you reuse the FilterResourceFileHandler to save and load the query > model. This results in a 'hybrid' log set file, where log file elements and > filter queries are in totally different models. The resulting log set file > looks a bit weird. > > 2). Step 1 is a quick fix for the problem. A more proper approach would be to > either (A) move log file element to EMF model and persist with EMF resource, or > (B) have a DTD mapping for the existing query model. Neither of them are not > simple changes and risky to be contain by 4.4 release. The current workaround > of the problem is to export filter and export log set in 2 different steps and > also import the 2 files in 2 different steps. It's not user-friendly but I > don't think it's a good idea to have a weird logset file which looks very > unprofessional. > > Eric, Dave. Since the suggested changes (A or B) in 2) above takes longer time > to be implements and the impact is big on the import log wizard structure, I > suggest to push this out from 4.4, and have a more formal change in the code > base to instead. Please advise. >
Hi Eugege, On 1) i agree that it does look weird, but that i guess is a limitation. i think the 'hybrid' logset file does not have anyother alternative .i.e. it would not make much sense to have duplicate filter definitions (multiple logs or logsets might use the same filter, what do you do in this case? Do you duplicate the filters? The XMI filter we have today are not necessarily the best representation of filters that we can duplicate with each log or logset). In order to avoid any duplication in the filter definitions in the logset file this approach has been adopted .i.e. only one instance of each of the filters used by the logs in all the logsets are exported into a filter dump available with each logset file.
Im not sure if moving the logset to EMF or having a DTD mapping of the existing query model would actually solve the problem that i describe above. Also im not sure if moving the logset itself to EMF is the right thing to do.
Also, isnt there a requirement to move to xpath based filters? I think this would open up a third option for a possible fix to this problem. xapth based filters are easier to represent.
And, i believe we should be taking some inputs from the effort on the common launch by Eric. (i remember we have some solution for this type of a problem)
Eric, Can you please add your comments on this.

In common launch in context, user can define filters using FilterDeclaration element, and reference the filters in their logs using FilterReference element.
For SimpleSearchQuery filters, what we do in common launch in context is to serialize them all as a parameter. Later on when user uses the context file to launch LTA in a different workspace, the parameter is deserialized back to SimpleSearchQuery filters.

Jane, please send the code to Rohit to see how we are doing this on the IBM side. I am OK to contribute this code.
Rohit, Jane has code to serialize/deserialize the FilterList in pure XML (not XMI). You will need to update the LogSet dtd to add this new ParameterList as an optional element.
We might be able to meet the deadline to fix the problem on time using Jane's code.

As per the discussion between Eric,Me and Eugene it was concluded that the only change that is required over the patch attached is to obfuscate the XMI related information from the Filter XML snippet attached by Eugene.

Created an attachment (id=65218) Patch for the defect
This patch over and above the previous patch does transformation to and from the XMI and obfuscated XML Filter representation.
Created an attachment (id=65219) Sample logset after the transformation ....
Please ignore the previous patch and use the latest one attached by me. Thank you!!!
(In reply to comment #18) Hi Rohit, you patch does not compile with the latest code. Would you please make sure it syncs with the latest CVS code?

Created an attachment (id=65283) Please apply this patch to the common UI package
Please appy this patch too. Sorry for missing it out previously.

Patches are reviewed and submitted to CVS.
Thanks a lot Vrushali and Rohit

bug.short_desc: List archives link incorrect on mailing list admin page

I won't bother fixing this if that's okay with you, as I wouldn't know where to start.

(In reply to comment #1) > I won't bother fixing this if that's okay with you, as I wouldn't know where to > start.
Because its deep in the guts of mailman rather than code we wrote? No chance that you could at least find that HTML blob that writes out the bogus links and just comment them out? (This goes with my philosophy of not having broken or out of date information on the website.)

It may be trivial to change, or perhaps I would need to update each of the 130 mailing lists we have - dunno, didn't bother to start looking. I figured that since it's only list admins that see that link, and there are only a very few list admins, that I wouldn't spend any time on it (part of my Bigger Fish To Fry philosophy), but okay... we'll fix it.
Of course we could hack an Apache rewrite rule as a quick-fix, but that goes against my Solve the Problem at the Root to Avoid Hacks philosophy.
Karl, can you fix this? Thanks.

Karl

bug.short_desc: [Viewers] NullPointerException on AbstractTreeViewer.remove(path, index)

long_desc.thetext:
I20061102-1715
It's possible to get an NPE when removing an element from a tree viewer. The remove API accepts a "parent path" and "child index". It is possible to specify an empty tree path for the parent to indicate the root element. However, the remove code eventually trys to find the widget associated with the "last segment" of the parent path. This results in null, and an NPE:

bug.short_desc: [1.5][compiler] Incorrect ambiguous method error

Released AmbiguousMethodTest#test044, active in R3_2_maintenance branch, inactive in HEAD branch.

Created an attachment (id=54414) Exploratory patch
The idea is to rawify only bounds that use type arguments in their definition, in order to stop recursive behaviors. Here, when creating the tiebreak method for <E extends Y<E>> X<E> foo(X<E> p), E would be substituted by Y#RAW (whereas in a concrete case like T extends Y<String> T would still be substituted by Y<String>). Do not release this patch as it is know (privileged speed).

Created an attachment (id=54477) Fix for this bug and bug 165620 + new test case
This new patch: - is cleaner than the previous one; - gets the modifications operated to fix 165620; - adds a test for the multi variables case (AmbiguousMethodTest#46).

I believe this one is tracked by bug 121024 (not digged into it, but the upper bound for the second method would be Object, which is not a Collection; if so, the suggestion for bug 121024 to keep more information into upper bounds should help).

bug.short_desc: JRE container is not initialized

long_desc.thetext:
Build: M3
Actually, this problem has been occurring for the past two weeks or so whenever I upgrade to a new build on an existing workspace.
All my projects have EE-based JRE container classpath entries. All of them have J2SE-1.4
I do have more than one JRE installed that is a perfect match to 1.4, although the default JRE is 1.5
For some reason, the JRE container shows up empty randomly on one of my projects when I start up.
I have to shut down and restart 1 or 2 times, and then things go back to normal.
So I don't have an exact reproducible scenario, but there certainly is a problem and I am wondering if the JRE initializer code was touched in the last little while as it may help to isolate the issue.
Screenshot to follow.

Created an attachment (id=53227) Non-initialized JRE
Observe the two J2SE-1.4 JREs. One is initialized correctly and the other one is empty causing build problems.
The JRE container code has not changed recently.

This bug is actually more severe than I thought. It is happening on my existing workspace at every startup, even when I shut down in a good state.
Let me try to come up with a reasonable-sized workspace to reproduce the problem on.

Darin, this problem is getting worse and worse.
Using I-20061213-0100, 10 projects don't compile because the J2SE-1.4 JRE container is not resolving to anything.
Do you log/trace anything when a container fails to initialize or return an empty list of classpath entries?
Sorry, no log or tracing. I have not seen this problem for a while.

I believe this is now fixed. There was a potential race condition in EnvironmentsManager.initializeCompatibilities() - The method checked a boolean flag, if false, set to true and did init stuff. If the init was not complete a second caller could return before the init is complete.
I added tracing the JREContainer and JREContainerInitializer. I found that once and a while a VM could not be resolved for a container because there were no compatible VMs. This would be the result if compatible VMs were not completely initialized and a second caller tried to get a compatbile VM.
Marking fixed. Will wait for Wassim to verify this solves his problem.
so far so good. let's claim success.
Verified.
In what build is this fixed? 3.3m4 and beyond?
Yes, it was fixed just before the 3.3 M4 build.

bug.short_desc: [CView] CView does not reveal new resources

Reason: CView.selectReveal(ISelection) calls SelectionConverter.convertSelectionToCElements - which converts objects of the selection to celements and ignores non-c resources.
See attached patch for changes. They are very small, so I think there is no need for further comments. I added an option to the selection converter which allows non-c elements, which cannot be converted, to be kept in the selection.

I have marked the clone of this bug as fixed. I'll leav this on 4.0 since it has the patch attached and I need it for the release review.

bug.short_desc: Creating projects should not create project level compiler settings

long_desc.thetext:
Creating a new Java Utility Project results in project level compiler settings being set. If all your projects are created this way, then it makes it hard to change settings at the workspace level.
For example if you want to use asserts, you can't use the default compiler compliance of 1.4, instead you need to set the Java source compliance to 1.4.
Project level settings should only be used if the user allows them, and the default should be for them not to be allowed.

Konstantin,
This is hitting our adopters when they have setup workspace wide compiler settings, and the java facet install overrides them without consulting the global setting. The project level settings should be optional.
Any way we can change this for 153....

This is working as designed.
The reason we set java compiler level at the project level is that the java compiler version is tied to the java facet version. If the two get out of sync, the user will get an error marker and will have to change one or the other to get them back in sync. Since project facets are project-level setting, making sure that the java compiler level is set at the project level provides the best user experience by making sure these settings are always managed in the same scope.
Suppose we tried to "optimize" this and only set the compiler level in the project if the selected java facet version matched workspace compiler level setting. If the user then imports the project into a workspace with a different workspace-level compiler setting, he would get an error. If after creating the project user changes the compiler level in the workspace such that it no longer matches the project, he would again get an error. This does not seem like desirable behavior in the majority of the situation, especially since the default version of the java facet (when creating a new project) is controlled by which runtime you select and not how your workspace java compiler level is configured.

(In reply to comment #2) > This is working as designed. > > The reason we set java compiler level at the project level is that the java > compiler version is tied to the java facet version. If the two get out of sync, > the user will get an error marker and will have to change one or the other to > get them back in sync. Since project facets are project-level setting, making > sure that the java compiler level is set at the project level provides the best > user experience by making sure these settings are always managed in the same > scope.
That's very circular reasoning. That an error is reported when they're out of sync isn't the issue.
> Suppose we tried to "optimize" this and only set the compiler level in the > project if the selected java facet version matched workspace compiler level > setting. If the user then imports the project into a workspace with a different > workspace-level compiler setting, he would get an error. If after creating the > project user changes the compiler level in the workspace such that it no longer > matches the project, he would again get an error. This does not seem like > desirable behavior in the majority of the situation, especially since the > default version of the java facet (when creating a new project) is controlled > by which runtime you select and not how your workspace java compiler level is > configured.
The compiler level only affects the minimum JRE level that can be used to launch the class files it creates. Most servers have an unrelated requirement on the JRE level used to run them, not on the version of the classes being run (if I misunderstand this, do correct me). JDT and Java itself allow for 1.4 classes to be run within a 1.5 environment; that the targetted server requires a 1.5 JRE to run shouldn't affect the compiler preferences at all.

(In reply to comment #3)
> That's very circular reasoning. That an error is reported when they're out > of sync isn't the issue.
What's so circular about this? The best user exprience is to keep these two settings in sync so that no errors are generated. Storing these two settings in the same scope (project-level) makes sure that this situation does not arise through a change external to project (such as a global settings change).
> The compiler level only affects the minimum JRE level that can be used to > launch the class files it creates. Most servers have an unrelated > requirement on the JRE level used to run them, not on the version of the > classes being run (if I misunderstand this, do correct me). JDT and Java > itself allow for 1.4 classes to be run within a 1.5 environment; that the > targetted server requires a 1.5 JRE to run shouldn't affect the compiler > preferences at all.
What I was trying to say is that when we are creating a new project we have to pick the default version of the java facet. Relying on the workspace settings for this does not work as there is no guarantee that the workspace level settings is compatible with the jre that the server is running on. Additionally, some runtime providers want to be able to control the default selected facets and versions when their runtime is selected.
Here is the actual heuristic that we use to pick the default java facet version:
if runtime is selected does runtime specify default version for the java facet? use that version else use the highest version supported by that runtime else use the compiler version from the workspace settings

(In reply to comment #2) I'm an adopter of WTP. Let me explain my situation, and what motivated this bug report.
I have an existing (large) J2EE application that is divided into 50 projects. This application runs on a 1.4.2 JVM, but it uses asserts, which forces us to set the Java source compatibility to 1.4 . (The default source compatibility level for JDK 1.4 compliance is 1.3).
When I use WTP on this existing application, it adds project level compiler options to my fifty projects. The problem is that they are all wrong, since they set the source compatibility back to 1.3. Any program that uses asserts (and there are thousands of them) dont compile.
There is no easy way to correct this, I need to manually edit fifty projects and remove these project level options.
What I need is a preference that I can set, that instructs WTP to not create project level options.
I'd very much like to see this targeted for 1.5.3 as I think this will really annoy some of our customers.

Gary,
There is a well-defined set of criteria that define each severity level (https://bugs.eclipse.org/bugs/page.cgi?id=fields.html#bug_severity). It is not appropriate to set this bug to severity critical.
Regarding, your request to make this change for 1.5.3, this change still needs significant design work and is risky because it changes behavior. I do not believe this change is appropriate for a service pack release especially considering that we have shipped with the current behavior since 1.0 release.

The problem is that I'm an adopter of WTP, and my customers are not coming from WTP 1.0, but rather from a precursor to WTP 1. They will view this as a bug, not an enhancement.
As I mentioned in my earlier comment, the change that I am asking for is very simple. Simply add a preference that says, do not generate project level compiler settings. If this is set, then simply dont generate compiler level settings, and let it be user beware.
*** Bug 176534 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. ***

bug.short_desc: Support offscreen rendering in a headless RCP

long_desc.thetext:
Consider the follwing use case:
A batch process (for instance a build process) produces an GMF diagram (for instance an Ecore model with an appropiate notation model) and invokes an headless RCP application which renders the generated diagram as an image (to be included in a generated web site).
I evaluated a headless RCP which uses OffscreenEditPartFactory and CopyToImageUtil to render a given diagram. The initialization of this RCP fails with the following exception:
org.eclipse.jface.util.Assert$AssertionFailedException: null argument; at org.eclipse.jface.util.Assert.isNotNull(Assert.java:150) at org.eclipse.jface.util.Assert.isNotNull(Assert.java:126) at org.eclipse.jface.resource.FontRegistry.<init>(FontRegistry.java:273) at org.eclipse.jface.resource.FontRegistry.<init>(FontRegistry.java:288) at org.eclipse.jface.resource.JFaceResources.getFontRegistry(JFaceResources.java:267) at org.eclipse.jface.resource.JFaceResources.getDefaultFont(JFaceResources.java:220) at org.eclipse.gmf.runtime.diagram.ui.preferences.AppearancePreferencePage.setDefaultFontPreference(AppearancePreferencePage.java:228) at org.eclipse.gmf.runtime.diagram.ui.preferences.AppearancePreferencePage.initDefaults(AppearancePreferencePage.java:169) at org.eclipse.gmf.runtime.diagram.ui.internal.DiagramUIPlugin.initializeDefaultDiagramPreferenceStore(DiagramUIPlugin.java:95) at org.eclipse.gmf.runtime.diagram.ui.internal.DiagramUIPlugin.start(DiagramUIPlugin.java:76) at org.eclipse.osgi.framework.internal.core.BundleContextImpl$2.run(BundleContextImpl.java:995)
Cherie Revells' comment: When the Diagram UI plugin starts up it initializes the preference store with font values. It is calling JFaceResources.getDefaultFont() and when a new font registry is created in SWT it requires a Display.
Compare the newsgroup thread http://dev.eclipse.org/newslists/news.eclipse.modeling.gmf/msg01826.html

bug.short_desc: refresh doesn't refresh when browsing the same folder on 2 connections

long_desc.thetext:
steps to reproduce: 1) create 2 connections to the same host 2) expand My Home on both connections 3) with the second connection expand a folder within My Home 4) with the first connection expand the same folder within My Home
The first connect expands to an empty directory and refresh on that directory will not resolve it (the parent needs to be refreshed).
Seen this problem on several occasions before, it's really annoying and should be fixed ASAP.
*** Bug 162707 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. ***

Saw the problem again with RSE I20061109-0800:
Have two connections to the same host (193.81.18.161), one via dstore-rexec (named "193.81.18.161-dstore-rexec"), the other via ssh (named "parser-ssh"). So the host name is exactly the same, but the host alias is not.
On both connections, have a connection-private filter named "RSETest" pointing to "My Home/RSETest".
Below RSETest, browse a folder/file hierarchy on both connections. On the SSH connection, drag and drop a file from RSETest/test.txt into folder RSETest/blah.
After that operation, the RSE Tree is refreshed, and I see RSETEst/blah under the dstore connection instead of under the ssh connection where I just was. The folder RSETest/blah looks empty, although I know it is not. It appears that the contents below RSETest/blah is ONLY shown under the ssh connection now, but not under the dstore connection.
I don't think that this is good for a NO-GO on the release since the prerequeisite seems to be that the host name is exactly the same. Still, for the future I'd suggest that IRemoteFile.equals() should also look at the host alias since there is no sense in treating files of different connections as equal.
-----------Enter bugs above this line----------- RSE 1.0 Release Test installation : eclipse-platform-3.3M3 RSE install : update-site RSE-complete java.runtime : Sun 1.5.0_08-b03 os.name: : Windows XP 5.1, Service Pack 1 ------------------------------------------------ systemtype : Windows-local, Dstore-win, Dstore-linux targetos : Red Hat Enterprise Linux WS release 4 (Nahant Update 3) targetuname : Linux parser 2.6.9-34.EL #1 i686 athlon i386 GNU/Linux targetvm : Sun Java HotSpot(TM) Client VM (build 1.4.2_12-b03, mixed mode) ------------------------------------------------

I guess that equality check needs to use the alias after all. When I had tried to hit this problem using connections with the exact same hostname before I couldn't reproduce it (even though I would have expected to).
I agree. Since the fix seems to be a safe one, I tend to allow tagging this for the 1.0 release. Can you check in the fix please?

Actually, I tried that and tested a bit but it seems to introduce an even worse problem. With that change, the follow problem occurs:
Steps: 1) expand My Home for both connections 2) in connection one, expand a directory 3) in connection two, expand the same directory
The contents of the directory in connection one end up being duplicated.

Ok, then we'll live with what we have for 1.0 - and work on a fix for 1.0.1 which is not too far out.
Please work on verifying other fixes now and give your GO/NO-GO.

Decreasing severity since the host address needs to be exactly the same now. Note that exactly the same address means that the cache directory for caching remote files would also be the same.
Consider a fix for 1.0.1
Verified. Appears to work as expected.

bug.short_desc: add property file to support signing

long_desc.thetext:
We will be turning on signing on our builds shortly in the 3.3 stream. The ant plugin is slightly different from other plugins in that nested jars should not be signed.
Please add an eclipse.inf file to your META-INF directory of ant plugin
jarprocessor.exclude.children.sign=true
This will exclude the nested jars from being signed when they are processed by the jar signing process that is invoked during the build.
Ok eclipse.inf file created and released.
closing
Verified.

bug.short_desc: Wrong order of classpath entries in self-hosting

long_desc.thetext:
Using I20061102-1715, I have the following problem. I have:
1) one plugin that has a bundle-classpath like this: lib.jar,. '.' corresponds to two output folders (bin1 and bin2)
2) a fragment based on that plugin that provides a lib.jar file. Since lib.jar is first on the bundle-classpath, I expect the classes inside the jar to be selected first. The jar contains types that are also available in the plugin '.' path through bin2.
I debugged this test case and the entries for this plugin are: bin1 bin2 lib.jar
This means that my "new" version of the classes (in lib.jar) are never picked up because they are always found in bin2. I would say that the dev classpath must respect the order specified in the bundle-classpath. lib.jar should definitely added before the two output folders from the plugin.
This is a pretty serious problem for me since I cannot self-host my actual setup. I will need to export the plugin and the fragment to a new target and run from that target hoping to be able to debug it.

while I'm not sure, this may well be a framework problem. As I recall, we take the dev time info given to us by PDE and put it at the front of the classpath rather than doing classpath surgery. Not really sure what to do here. It would be very unfortunate if we had to add alot of complex classpath manipulation code in the framework to support the dev scenarios. Another option would be to see if PDE could shoulder more of the burden and actually compute the new classpaths for us entirely?! Wassim has broad shoulders and Brian is a sturdy young lad. Whaddya think?

Jeff is correct. The runtime sticks dev classpath entries before the others. This is an issue for any patch fragment scenario.
I agree with Jeff, I would like to keep complicated dev classpath computation out of the framework (no surprise to Wassim ;-). In this case PDE should add an absolute path to the fragment's lib.jar output folder to the host's dev.properties entry.

PDE should at least respect the order specified in the bundle-classpath entry of the MANIFEST.MF file, otherwise the self-hosting scenario is broken. Or PDE allows the user to change the order of the output folders added to the plugin classpath in selfhosting.

Just to clarify, the current problem is not PDE's but Equinox's. The problem can be solved either in Equinox or PDE. Tom and I are suggesting that it is a candidate for being solved in PDE as it is a tooling-time issue and it would allow the framework code to be simplified and thus be more efficient.

I agree that the problem should be solved at the PDE end. It can only be done accurately by starting to match up Bundle-Classpath entries with build.properties entries to map JARs to output folders. Only PDE has access to this kind of info. However, if the user does not have build.properties or if it's stale, they may be adversely affected by this.
Plus, Tom won't have time to address this at the Equinox level, seeing that he's busy these days making the state more resilient in the face of unresolved imports and all :)
This matter requires the delicate care of Brian.

I wanted to make sure to understand this completely before starting to try to fix anything. Olivier's report does not say whether or not the lib.jar is a binary jar or in compiled in the fragment's source folder. If it is a source folder, I think things are not as complicated.
So just as a worst case scenario, imagine the fragment's jar is a binary jar. If we add an absolute path to the jar, would we run into the duplicate entries for ClassLoader.getResources as in bug 108466?
Just to make sure we know the limitations, I believe we can run into a misordered dev.properties classpath with the fix from 108466. If the user creates a plugin with a "Bundle-Classpath: lib.jar, ." where lib.jar is a binary jar in the plug-in porject. With bug 108466, we would exclude lib.jar from the dev.properties and instead only include the output directories. This would cause classes to be looked up in the wrong order (I believe).
Just wanted to make sure I understand what is going on as much as possible :)

Brian,
The point here is that there is no output folder corresponding to library.jar.
Here is how I picture it would work:
Given a "Bundle-Classpath: library.jar, .", here is how the dev.properties value for the plug-in should be composed:
1. Look in the build.properties for a source.library.jar key. If it exists, then you put the output folders corresponding to the source folders on the classpath and move on to the next library (ie. the dot). If no source.library.jar exists, you look for a physical library by that name in the plug-in. In Olivier's case, you will find it and it will therefore be put first on the classpath.
2. Move on to the next entry in Bundle-Classpath (the dot) and do the same as in #1.

After conversing with Tom and Wassim, the algorithm proposed is similar to Wassim's comment above.
To compute a Plug-in Projects dev.properties we read the Bundle-Classpath to find the libraries and do the following algorithm:
1. Search the plug-in project's build.properties to find a source entry. If found, add to dev.properties
2. If there is no source entry, look for a binary library representing the library. If found, do NOT include it in the dev.properties. This will prevent reintroducing bug 108466.
3. If we can't find a source entry or physical file, find all fragments included in the launch configuration. For each fragment, look in the build.properties for source entry. If it exists, add it to the plug-in's dev.properties. If it does not exist, look for the physical file in the fragment's project. If it exists, add it to the plug-in's dev.properties. If not, move on to next fragment.
Drawback: Since we don't check if a fragment is resolved, we could include a reference to an unresolved fragment (a linux fragment in a win32 env.). To check to see if a fragment would resolved when launched could be time consuming (possibly requiring creating a resolver state whenever we launch).
Before I start doing too much work, I wanted to make sure everyone was in agreement with this algorithm. Please comment away :)

Should you only do step 3 for fragments that have the "Eclipse-PatchFragment: true" header? This would reduce the concern over placing jars from random unresolved fragments on the host classpath.
In step 1 you should continue to use relative paths in the dev.properties when an output folder is found in the host (e.g. bin).
In step 3 you will need to use absolute paths to the output folder or binary library of the fragment (e.g. /myworkspace/my.fragment/bin)
Brian, while you in this area of the code take a look at bug 164817 that I just opened.

If we base our calculations off Eclipse-PatchFragment, we are limiting this functionality to Eclipse, right? If so, I would like to try to be as OSGi independent as possible since we are encouraging the use of other OSGi platforms with our recent work.

Should be fixed in 3.3M4.
Modified org.eclipse.pde.internal.core.ClasspathHelper v1.16 for both this bug and bug 164817.

bug.short_desc: Report generation via ASF works with 4.2.1 but fails with 4.3

long_desc.thetext:
The two examples: "Generating test reports from ant scripts" and "Customizing test reports from ant scripts" under http://help.eclipse.org/help32/index.jsp?topic=/org.eclipse.hyades.test.doc.user/tasks/texecuting-the-test-execution-service.htm don't work in TPTP 4.3. Both examples throw the following exception:
java.lang.NullPointerException at org.eclipse.tptp.test.report.birt.services.TestSuitesPublicationService.publish(TestSuitesPublicationService.java:70) at org.eclipse.hyades.test.core.services.AbstractTestResultsPublicationService.execute(AbstractTestResultsPublicationService.java:105) at org.eclipse.hyades.automation.server.AbstractService.execute(AbstractService.java:43) at org.eclipse.hyades.automation.server.ServiceProxy$1.run(ServiceProxy.java:140) at org.eclipse.hyades.automation.core.utils.ReusableThread.run(ReusableThread.java:131) at java.lang.Thread.run(Unknown Source)
The same scripts run fine using TPTP 4.2.1. Here's one of the scripts that I used:
<project name="TPTP Automatable Services Tutorial" default="main" xmlns:tptp="antlib:org.eclipse.hyades.automation.client.adapters.ant">
<!-- Define common properties for all automatable services --> <property name="tptp.test.workspace" value="D:\Temp\test-pass"/> <property name="tptp.test.project" value="plug-in" /> <property name="tptp.test.connection" value="tptp:rac://localhost:10002/default"/> <property name="tptp.automation.eclipse" value="D:\TPTP4.3\TPTP-4.3.0-200609220100\eclipse" /> <!-- Define script-local properties, that vary by installation --> <property name="project.dir" value="${tptp.test.workspace}\${tptp.test.project}"/> <property name="report.publication.location" location="d:/temp" /> <property name="tptp.publication.service" value="org.eclipse.tptp.test.report.birt.publish-testsuites"/> <!-- Run the report --> <target name="main" depends="test-results-publication"/> <target name="set-date-range"> <!-- Use standard ant tstamp mechanisms to specify the desired date range --> <!-- This example uses a range between today and 60 days days prior --> <tstamp> <format property="startDateTime" pattern="MM/dd/yyyy hh:mm aa" offset="-60" unit="day"/> </tstamp> <tstamp> <format property="endDateTime" pattern="MM/dd/yyyy hh:mm aa"/> </tstamp> </target> <!-- Publish test suite results report --> <target name="test-results-publication" depends="set-date-range"> <echo message="Publishing test suite results report..." /> <tptp:publication report="${report.publication.location}/report.html" reportTemplateLocation="D:\TPTP4.3\TPTP-4.3.0-200609220100\eclipse\plugins\org.eclipse.tptp.test.report.birt_4.2.0.v200609090100\templates\TabularReport.rptdesign" startDateTime="${startDateTime}" endDateTime="${endDateTime}" > <fileset dir="${project.dir}"> <include name="**/*.testsuite" /> </fileset> </tptp:publication> </target> </project>

There is a code error in the "org.eclipse.tptp.test.report.birt.publish-testsuites" publication service.
The work around is to use the more generic ant service. <property name="tptp.publication.service" value="org.eclipse.tptp.test.report.birt.publish-tabular-testsuites" />
With this service the reportTemplateLocation is an id as shown instead of the location of the report template: reportTemplateLocation="org.eclipse.tptp.test.report.birt.internal.TabularTPFTestSuiteReportElement"
The report parameter is now a directory name instead of a particular file name as follows:
report="${report.dir}"
Try the following build file.
<!-- Define common properties for all automatable services --> <property name="tptp.test.workspace" value="D:\Temp\test-pass"/> <property name="tptp.test.project" value="plug-in" /> <property name="tptp.test.connection" value="tptp:rac://localhost:10002/default"/> <property name="tptp.automation.eclipse" value="D:\TPTP4.3\TPTP-4.3.0-200609220100\eclipse" /> <!-- Define script-local properties, that vary by installation --> <property name="project.dir" value="${tptp.test.workspace}\${tptp.test.project}"/> <property name="report.publication.location" location="d:/temp" /> <property name="tptp.publication.service" value="org.eclipse.tptp.test.report.birt.publish-tabular-testsuites"/> <!-- Run the report --> <target name="main" depends="test-results-publication"/> <target name="set-date-range"> <!-- Use standard ant tstamp mechanisms to specify the desired date range --> <!-- This example uses a range between today and 60 days days prior --> <tstamp> <format property="startDateTime" pattern="MM/dd/yyyy hh:mm aa" offset="-60" unit="day"/> </tstamp> <tstamp> <format property="endDateTime" pattern="MM/dd/yyyy hh:mm aa"/> </tstamp> </target> <!-- Publish test suite results report --> <target name="test-results-publication" depends="set-date-range"> <echo message="Publishing test suite results report..." /> <tptp:publication report="${report.publication.location}"
reportTemplateLocation="org.eclipse.tptp.test.report.birt.internal.TabularTPFTestSuiteReportElement" startDateTime="${startDateTime}" endDateTime="${endDateTime}" > <fileset dir="${project.dir}"> <include name="**/*.testsuite" /> </fileset> </tptp:publication> </target> </project>
Changing target to 4.4 since there's a workaround. A readme entry should be added.
Created an attachment (id=53239) patch that will fix other ant services
Lowering severity since there's a workaround.
Applied Patch.

<project name="TPTPtests" default="tptp.tests" xmlns:tptp="antlib:org.eclipse.hyades.automation.client.adapters.ant">

<property name="tptp.test.workspace" value="D:/Project1" /> <property name="tptp.test.project" value="IFA" /> <property name="tptp.test.connection" value="tptp:rac://localhost:10002/default"/> <property name="tptp.automation.eclipse" value="C:/eclipse" /> <!-- <property name="tptp.publication.service" value="org.eclipse.tptp.test.report.birt.publish-tabular-testsuites"/> -->
<tstamp> <format property="datetimestamp" pattern="yyyyMMdd-HHmm" locale="en" /> </tstamp>
<property name="project.dir" value="${tptp.test.workspace}/${tptp.test.project}"/> <property name="report.publication.location" location="D:/temp" /> <property name="project.build.identifier" value="${report.publication.location}/${tptp.test.project}-${datetimestamp}" />
<target name="tptp.tests" depends="clean.temp, test.execution, test.results.publication" />
<!-- clean up -->
<target name="clean.temp">
<delete failonerror="false"> <fileset dir="${env.TEMP}" includes="**/*.dat" /> </delete>
<delete failonerror="false"> <fileset dir="${tptp.test.workspace}/${tptp.test.project}" includes="**/*.execution" /> </delete>
<delete failonerror="false"> <fileset dir="${env.TEMP}" includes="**/*.tmp" /> </delete>
</target>
<!-- Start date and End date for HTML Reports publication -->
<target name="set-date-range"> <tstamp> <format property="stDtTime" pattern="MM/dd/yyyy hh:mm aa" offset="-60" unit="day"/> </tstamp>
<tstamp> <format property="enDtTime" pattern="MM/dd/yyyy hh:mm aa"/> </tstamp> </target>
<!-- Test Executions -->
<target name="test.execution"> <echo message="Executing test suite" /> <tptp:execution resultsrefid="tptp.test.results"> <fileset dir="${project.dir}"> <include name="**/*.testsuite"/> </fileset> </tptp:execution> </target>
<!-- Test results publication -->
<target name="test.results.publication" depends="set-date-range"> <echo message="Publishing test suite results report..." /> <tptp:publication report="${report.publication.location}/${tptp.test.project}.html" reportTemplateLocation="C:\eclipse\plugins\org.eclipse.tptp.test.report.birt_4.3.0.200701021240\templates\TestExecution.rptdesign" startDateTime="${stDtTime}" endDateTime="${enDtTime}"> <filelist refid="tptp.test.results"/> </tptp:publication> </target>
</project>

The fix included in tha attached patch was *not* included in 4.3.1, which means that the basic test-result-publication ASF service throws an NPE in 4.3.1.
Though I hope we don't have one, if a 4.3.1.1 release happens, this should definitely be included. I need to hack my eclipsecon tutorial to try to work around this and still show ant report generation after test execution. I believe from the comments that I can do it by specifying a date range and passing in the test suites instead of the result files, but in normal continuous integration work, you already know the result files you want to report on.

I applied the attached patch, and while it resolves the initial NPE, the main reporting ant script from the help still does not work. The help link is the same one Ali pasted at the top of the defect. I will paste the ant script from the help topic below.
This service was written to accept either .execution files or .testsuite files as input. If .testsuites are the input, it should use the specified date range to calculate the .execution files for the report. If .execution files are the direct input, then they should simply be used. This is how it worked in 4.2.1
<project name="TPTP Automatable Services Tutorial" default="main" xmlns:tptp="antlib:org.eclipse.hyades.automation.client.adapters.ant">
<!-- Define common properties for all automatable services --> <property name="tptp.test.workspace" value="C:\eclipsecon\eclipse\workspace"/> <property name="tptp.test.project" value="TPTPJUnitTests" /> <property name="tptp.test.connection" value="tptp:rac://localhost:10002/default"/> <property name="tptp.automation.eclipse" value="C:\eclipseconwb_birt\eclipse" /> <!-- Define script-local properties, that vary by installation --> <property name="project.dir" value="${tptp.test.workspace}\${tptp.test.project}"/> <property name="report.publication.location" location="c:/temp" /> <target name="main" depends="test-execution, test-results-publication"/> <!-- Execute test suites using default results name --> <target name="test-execution"> <echo message="Executing test suite..." /> <tptp:execution resultsrefid="tptp.test.results"> <fileset dir="${project.dir}"> <include name="**/*.testsuite"/> </fileset> </tptp:execution> </target> <!-- Publish test suite results report --> <target name="test-results-publication"> <echo message="Publishing test suite results report..." /> <tptp:publication report="${report.publication.location}/report.html"> <filelist refid="tptp.test.results"/> </tptp:publication> </target> </project>

(In reply to comment #32) As mentioned in my last comment#28 as my last effort to resolve this, but failed, I could not make it happen (get the test reports), so I left, becuase getting everything free and open source, and of course good work as a whole, thought not to complain too much.
Thanks.

Just so that I'm clear the problem is when .execution files are provided? The other scenarios are okay?
I think part of the problem is that there isn't enough test case coverage. I will add some test cases for this scenario.

(In reply to comment #34) Yes, Sheldon, as far as I have tested it, only gives the problems when .execution files are provided.
