bug.short_desc: CStructure's getScope() always return the global scope
[Browser] Since Installing IE7 Internal Web Browser ( or Online Help ) Crashes JVM

long_desc.thetext:
I just found out that when I select Help > Help Contents in both our Eclipse-based product as well as in the Eclipse 3.2.1 SDK, sometime after the Help window appears, the JVM will always crash. There is nothing in the .log file, and there is no JVM crash log to be found either.
I have tried deleting the configuration area, re-installing, running in a fresh workspace...everything. The *only* thing I can think of that I did recently was to install Internet Explorer 7. If I tell Eclipse to use an external browser, then I can view the help system. Even if I view it in IE7 externally! But putting the Help system back to the internal browser causes the crash to re-appear.
Could this be a SWT-related thing with IE7?
Actually, I just tried creating a simple .html file in Eclipse and opening in the built in web browser/editor. Browsing to the eclipse.org site and clicking around for a few seconds causes the JVM to crash as well. Looks like an internal browser bug related to IE7 on WinXP.
Grant, please investigate and fix.
I hope you guys can reproduce this and it isn't just me. ;) Let me know if you need anything from me testing-wise, or if you need more information.

I haven't been able to reproduce this with IE7 on XP. Opening/using/closing Help Contents several times hasn't crashed, nor has clicking around eclipse.org in the internal browser view.
Try running regedt32 and go to HKEY_CLASSES_ROOT/Shell.Explorer. What are its CLS_ID and CurVer values? Also, below it you should see at least Shell.Explorer.1 and Shell.Explorer.2. Are there any more (eg.- Shell.Explorer.3)?

I only have Shell.Explorer, Shell.Explorer.1, and Shell.Explorer.2. Here is what is in my registry:
[HKEY_CLASSES_ROOT\Shell.Explorer] @="Microsoft Web Browser"
[HKEY_CLASSES_ROOT\Shell.Explorer\CLSID] @="{8856F961-340A-11D0-A96B-00C04FD705A2}"
[HKEY_CLASSES_ROOT\Shell.Explorer\CurVer] @="Shell.Explorer.2"
[HKEY_CLASSES_ROOT\Shell.Explorer.1] @="Microsoft Web Browser"
[HKEY_CLASSES_ROOT\Shell.Explorer.1\CLSID] @="{EAB22AC3-30C1-11CF-A7EB-0000C05BAE0B}"
[HKEY_CLASSES_ROOT\Shell.Explorer.2] @="Microsoft Web Browser"
[HKEY_CLASSES_ROOT\Shell.Explorer.2\CLSID] @="{8856F961-340A-11D0-A96B-00C04FD705A2}"
And here is what those GUIDs resolve to:
[HKEY_CLASSES_ROOT\CLSID\{8856F961-340A-11D0-A96B-00C04FD705A2}] @="Microsoft Web Browser"
[HKEY_CLASSES_ROOT\CLSID\{8856F961-340A-11D0-A96B-00C04FD705A2}\Control] @=""
[HKEY_CLASSES_ROOT\CLSID\{8856F961-340A-11D0-A96B-00C04FD705A2}\InProcServer32] @="C:\\WINDOWS\\system32\\ieframe.dll" "ThreadingModel"="Apartment"
[HKEY_CLASSES_ROOT\CLSID\{8856F961-340A-11D0-A96B-00C04FD705A2}\MiscStatus] @="0"
[HKEY_CLASSES_ROOT\CLSID\{8856F961-340A-11D0-A96B-00C04FD705A2}\MiscStatus\1] @="131473"
[HKEY_CLASSES_ROOT\CLSID\{8856F961-340A-11D0-A96B-00C04FD705A2}\ProgID] @="Shell.Explorer.2"
[HKEY_CLASSES_ROOT\CLSID\{8856F961-340A-11D0-A96B-00C04FD705A2}\ToolboxBitmap32] @="C:\\WINDOWS\\system32\\ieframe.dll, 257"
[HKEY_CLASSES_ROOT\CLSID\{8856F961-340A-11D0-A96B-00C04FD705A2}\TypeLib] @="{EAB22AC0-30C1-11CF-A7EB-0000C05BAE0B}"
[HKEY_CLASSES_ROOT\CLSID\{8856F961-340A-11D0-A96B-00C04FD705A2}\Version] @="1.1"
[HKEY_CLASSES_ROOT\CLSID\{8856F961-340A-11D0-A96B-00C04FD705A2}\VersionIndependentProgID] @="Shell.Explorer"
and:
[HKEY_CLASSES_ROOT\CLSID\{EAB22AC3-30C1-11CF-A7EB-0000C05BAE0B}] @="Microsoft Web Browser Version 1"
[HKEY_CLASSES_ROOT\CLSID\{EAB22AC3-30C1-11CF-A7EB-0000C05BAE0B}\InProcServer32] @="C:\\WINDOWS\\system32\\ieframe.dll" "ThreadingModel"="Apartment"
[HKEY_CLASSES_ROOT\CLSID\{EAB22AC3-30C1-11CF-A7EB-0000C05BAE0B}\MiscStatus] @="0"
[HKEY_CLASSES_ROOT\CLSID\{EAB22AC3-30C1-11CF-A7EB-0000C05BAE0B}\MiscStatus\1] @="131473"
[HKEY_CLASSES_ROOT\CLSID\{EAB22AC3-30C1-11CF-A7EB-0000C05BAE0B}\ProgID] @="Shell.Explorer.1"
[HKEY_CLASSES_ROOT\CLSID\{EAB22AC3-30C1-11CF-A7EB-0000C05BAE0B}\ToolboxBitmap32] @="C:\\WINDOWS\\system32\\ieframe.dll, 257"
[HKEY_CLASSES_ROOT\CLSID\{EAB22AC3-30C1-11CF-A7EB-0000C05BAE0B}\TypeLib] @="{EAB22AC0-30C1-11CF-A7EB-0000C05BAE0B}"
[HKEY_CLASSES_ROOT\CLSID\{EAB22AC3-30C1-11CF-A7EB-0000C05BAE0B}\Version] @="1.1"
[HKEY_CLASSES_ROOT\CLSID\{EAB22AC3-30C1-11CF-A7EB-0000C05BAE0B}\VersionIndependentProgID] @="Shell.Explorer"

So your registry didn't change either. It appears that IE7 does not ship with a new control for embedding, though the installation may have updated some libraries that the control uses.
Can you find any other steps that make this happen reliably? Though your description in comment 0 should be good enough, I'm not seeing the crash. It's strange that there aren't other reports of this so far given the rapid adoption of IE7. Maybe the steps to make it crash are a little more precise than currently believed (?).

I just tried it again and was able to make it crash. Here is exactly what I did:
Test #1:
- Took a virgin Eclipse 3.2.1 "platform-only" zipfile (to remove all extra features and plugins from the equation), and unzipped to a folder.
- Ran eclipse.exe, and created a new workspace in a new folder
- Clicked Goto Workbench on the Welcome screen
- Clicked Help > Help Contents, and instant JVM crash after the Help Window appears.
Test #2
- Took a virgin Eclipse 3.2.1 "platform-only" zipfile (to remove all extra features and plugins from the equation), and unzipped to a folder.
- Ran eclipse.exe, and created a new workspace in a new folder
- Clicked Goto Workbench on the Welcome screen
- Created a new, simple project
- Created a new .html file called test.html
- When this new file opened in the internal web browser, I manually browsed to "www.eclipse.org"
- Then I just started clicking. I clicked maybe 30 times and nothing happened. I then and resized the editor area a bit and started clicking again. After maybe 20 more clicks or so, it crashed the JVM.
I don't think it is any link in particular that does it. It just is a random thing.
The problem is, there is nothing in the .log file, and there is no JVM crash log anywhere. I have absolutely no other info to give you except the Windows detailed information regarding the crash - which I think is pretty much useless.

Dunno if it helps, but the JVM exit code is -1073741819
It also appears to be slightly random crashing when executing Help > Help Contents as well. It did it 3 times in a row, and then would not do it. Shutting down Eclipse, restarting and performing the same following steps:
- Run eclipse.exe
- Click Help > Help Contents
Causes a crash maybe 60%-70% of the time. I *thought* it had soemthing to do with me having another Eclipse (my development workbench) running in the background, and whether it was maximized or minimized, but more testing seems to indicate it is pseudo-random. If I confirm anything else, I'll let you know.

I've tried running in debug mode with tracing turned on for SWT as well as for all of the Help system but I get no real interesting output. I'll spend some time to see if I can't debug this in a runtime workbench to see where it is failing. We will also get some other people here to install IE7 to verify that this bug goes beyond my machine.

For what it is worth, we can't reproduce this on anyone else's machine either. So I guess there something has gone awry with my laptop, although I can't figure out what it is right now. I have tried removing a lot of extraneous codecs and things of that nature with no luck. If I can narrow this down I will post my results here, but for now it looks like I am the only one who is seeing this behaviour.
I have the same problem! I have a dell D600 laptop with XP SP2.
Interesting! I have a Dell Latitude D810.
I does not always crash but about 2 out of 3 times I open help. Have you tried a minimal SWT application with a browser widget?

I also tried it with the SWT examples JAR, in particular the browser demo (org.eclipse.swt.examples_3.1.100.v3232n, with org.eclipse.swt_3.2.1.v3235e.jar) and after awhile it will crash clicking through various webpages. It took a few minutes but it did crash.
I wonder what common "other software" we may have installed?
I have the google bar and webresearch (http://www.macropool.com/en/index.html) installed.

Hi Michael, Have you by any chance uninstalled the Dell Quickset application, or the Dell Notebook System Software? I have recently updated my laptop with the latest stuff from the Dell support site. I installed 3 things:
1) A Bluetooth driver update 2) A new version of Dell Quickset (which I had *uninstalled* because it annoyed me). 3) The Dell Notebook System Software (not sure if I ever removed this or if I never had it...)
Anyway - now it looks like my problem is gone. I can't seem to be able to get it to crash - even with your snippet.
For what it is worth - my version Dell Quickset is 7.1.12.
My Dell Notebook System Software should be v.4.5.0, A21, but I can't see what this adds to my system, except for an .inf file for what looks like the system processor.
I'd be inclined to say that re-installing Quickset has done something for me, but I'm not sure at this point. I updated these last week and just noticed now that my browser doesn't crash. I'm not sure if IT has "pushed" any other updates on my machine since then...

Oh! The other thing I did was recently update Google Desktop! I installed from an executable called GoogleDesktopSetup.exe version 5.0.611.15590. I'm not sure the previous version I had installed. I can't see any way of actually getting a version out of it. This is another likely candidate for something that fixed my crashing problems but I hav eno real way to verify that.

Cool. Well - I guess this can be resolved. But it would be nice to know what Google Desktop was doing to IE7 that was so bad.
Thanks for helping track this down, Michael!

Agreed, thanks for helping track this down Michael. This is good information to have, and if others report similar problems then they can be pointed at this report as a case to investigate on their machine. Closing as WORKSFORME.
Actually, WONTFIX is what we do with bugs that we CANTFIX.
CANTFIX, ALREADYFIXED, ...

Th problem was caused by the following version: Google Desktop 4.2006.0627.0443-en-pb After installing the following version the problem was gone: Google Desktop 5.0.0611.15590-en-pb
I recovered the old version from my backup (to find out the version number). However, with the 'recover' version I did not see the problem anymore. This could be, because I recovered only the files in C:\Program Files\Google\Google Desktop Search. Maybe some other files that were installed (or some registry settings) caused the problem...
Thanks for getting back to us with the details.

bug.short_desc: First connection created is shown duplicate in tree

long_desc.thetext:
Start Eclipse SDK 3.2.1 with an empty workspace. Get RSE-runtime-core and ssh from update site (no local!) Switch to RSE Perspective. Press New connection button, select ssh, enter hostname, press finish ---> The resulting connection is shown twice in the tree.
I suppose the problem is there because the "Local" connection which usually always takes the first place is not installed.
-----------Enter bugs above this line----------- RSE 1.0 Testing round 3 installation : Eclipse SDK 3.2.1 (M20060921-0945), cdt-sdk-3.1.1 RSE install : update-site RSE-runtime-core, ssh, dstore, remotecdt java.runtime : Sun 1.5.0_07-b03 os.name: : Windows XP Home 5.1, Service Pack 2 ------------------------------------------------ systemtype : Linux-dstore targetos : Red Hat Enterprise Linux WS release 4 (Nahant Update 3) targetvm : Sun 1.4.2_12-b03 --------------------------------------
Reproduced the issue today on Linux-gtk, with Eclipse-3.2 --> setting All Platforms
Seen that issue during re-working the new connection wizard and fixed it for 2.0.
see comment#2

VERIFICATION FAILED: with Eclipse-3.3M5eh / RSE-2.0M5
Checked with eclipse-SDK-3.3M5eh-win32 on WinXP SP2, Sun Java 1.5.0_11 Went to http://download.eclipse.org/dsdp/tm/updates/milestones Got only RSE-Runtime-Core and RSE-Local Press "New Connection" Button in RSE System View
--> The New connection wizard also shows the "Local" System type although it should be disabled (filed as bug 176749)
Enter a host name, press finish
--> The newly created connection is shown twice.
Works for me in exact this configuration without having the second node at all.

If asuming the same typo here as within bug#176749.
The local system node is invalid created even if the system type is disabled.

I've fixed the problem with the invalid creation of the local system node if the system type is enabled. Still, the second node is shown the first time. I've debugged this down to the content provider and SystemRegistry.getSystemViewRoots(). Both are absolutly returning arrays with only a single element!!! I have no idea where the second node is coming from.
There is another problem with the properties. There are not correctly shown in the dialog. The properties view is doing it correctly.
As the second node is problematic, re-assigning to daveM for investigation.

What seems to happen is that the first connection gets added to the tree twice (the 2nd time via the ADD_RELATIVE event). I've added duplicate checking in the SystemView for ADD and ADD_RELATIVE events. This prevents the duplicates from being added.
Apparently fixed in M6.
Verified with I20070405-0600 on Windows (runtime-ssh only). Closing.

bug.short_desc: Extensibility for DiagramEventBroker broken

long_desc.thetext:
It is possible to extend the DiagramEventBroker right now, but it is broken...
DiagramEventBrokerThreadSafe is package protected. Anyone extending DiagramEventBroker would therefore break the threading behavior. Perhaps this functionality should be folded into DiagramEventBroker?
DiagramEventBroker#getInterestedNotificationListeners is final. This is one of the main reasons to override DiagramEventBroker in order to broadcast an event to a set of derived semantic criteria without adding explicit listeners.
I'll be happy to address this in the form of a patch... Assign to me if desired.
fireNotification needs to be "protected" rather than "private" as well...

Created an attachment (id=57565) Patch for DiagramEventBroker Extensibility
This patch opens up extensibility for the DiagramEventBroker. The DiagramEventBrokerThreadSafe has been eliminated and replaced by a ResourceSetHandler mechanism that allows internal clients to register a different handler. This makes it possible for external clients to register a different DiagramEventBroker without eliminating the functionality of the DiagramEventBrokerThreadSafe.

Note: there is also a possible race condition to do with when the overriden DiagramEventBroker gets installed. Currently it is reliant on plug-in loading which creates an opening where the default broker will be active for a duration. Investigation needs to be done whether the current mechanism (api to register) needs to be replaced with a Service or extension point mechanism instead.
Agreed that this work can be done in the 2.0 stream.

After a discussion with Steve and Gelb ; we agreed on a set of changes that need to be done to the diagram event broker
i'm going to do these changes on stages 1- allowing clients to extended the diagram event broker by removing the final key word from some methods, and making some methods protected instead of final 2- Allowing sub classes of the diagram event broker to forward events on deletd objects to listeners 3- trying to get ride of the DiagramEventBrokerThreadSafe 4- handling the some issues with the Diagram event broker factory
stage 1 and 2 are done
stage 4 is delivered
Since GMF 2.0 M6 was released April 5, 2007, doing a bulk move of all open Bugzillas currently on M6 to 2.0 M7. Owners will need to access if the issue really is targetted for 2.0 M7.
I think this Bugzilla is complete?

(In reply to comment #10) > I think this Bugzilla is complete?
No it is not

The only remaining piece is to get ride of the Diagram event broker thread safe since it will require clients to copy code to get there diagram event broker working otherwise they will have threading problems
Client has copied code from GMF into his application.

bug.short_desc: When a debug perspective is removed, and user in a debug session, the debug session should be disconnected

long_desc.thetext:
When user closes the debug perpective, and is still in a debugging session (either with or without knowing), currently, Eclispe just immediately closes the debug perpective, and the user would have no idea that a debug session is still active. This some time may cause a problem.
Instead of immediately close the perpective, it would be nice for Eclipse to either (1) provide some notification to the user that a debug session is still active and whether the user would like to disconnect from it, or (2) it would be nice for Eclipse framework to provide an event notification mechanism, so that any listener can perform *something* before a perspective is closed (ie. disconnect or terminating a debug session).
For (2) - the workbench provides notification when a perspective (page) is closed. See IPageListener.
Deferred

bug.short_desc: Regression: MyFileTransferClient fails to xfer /etc/termcap correctly

long_desc.thetext: On Linux-IA32 and Linux-EM64t (but not on Linux-IPF!), when I run the MyFileTransferClient C++ smoke test (from the SDK package) it fails. The first time I did it the file was bigger... subsequently smaller. But I've not see it be the same size on that file on those systems.

Okay, my initial failure was on our Linux-EM64T build machine, sw-opt002. Kevin then confirmed on sw-opt007, a Linux-IA32 box. But I can *not* get it to break on our Linux-IA32 build machine, sw-opt001! Just an FYI that this one might be a flaky one!
Being investigated. If it's flaky, may not be a regression. Need to revisit the severity setting as this doesn't need seem like it should block 4.3.

I saw a similiar issue on our 007 machine... I believe that the issue was specific to shared memory partitions not be cleaned on the machine.
I tested on 001 and 006 and was not able to reproduce this issue.

Okay, so we have *TWO* machines on two different platforms that exhibit the problem... sw-opt007 is a Linux-IA32 machine, and sw-opt002 is a Linux-EM64T system. We have three machines where we cannot duplicate the problem... 001, 006, and 023, which are Linux-IA32 and Linux-IPF machines.
So when shared memory was cleaned up on 007, did 007 successfully pass the test?
Kevin - please respond to Randy's query. Your comment #3 is unclear as to whether manually freeing up the shared memory resolved the problem or not.
Added effort estimate: 5 days
Randy, I can't reproduce the bug on the machines sw-opt002 and sw-opt007. Do you still have the issue?

Igor, if you can't reproduce it, then I assume the various fixes that have gone in took care of this. All I would want confirmation on is that you specifically tried transferring */etc/termcap*. That was the one sole file we had problems with. If that file transferred correctly, I think you can close this.
Randy, Yes I tested transfering of the /etc/termcap file. Length and content of the source and destination files (I used diff command) were the same.
Resolving as "works for me"

bug.short_desc: fileExtension is deprecated but doesn't offer alternatives in schema description

long_desc.thetext:
PDE loves the debug framework very much. However, we are a bit puzzled about the fileExtension element. It's been deprecated but I can't find a description of what to use in its place. Can the debug team please clarify?
... The fileExtension element is deprecated <!ELEMENT fileExtension EMPTY>
<!ATTLIST fileExtension ...

This element has actually not been used since before launch configurations. It should have been deprecated long ago. Instead, we use launch shortcuts. This element was used in the days of the launch wizard to determine what default launcher should be used for a ".java" file, for example.
Updated doc to point to the launch shortcuts extension point.

I guess we're just catching up with the PDE tooling (which we also love), and we've just found out about the "deprecated" radio button in the schema editor.
Please verify, Mike.
cc Markus as I'm sure he'd have the same problem in jdt/ui
verified
chris, I am dying to know what the updated doc says.

I found (and deleted) references to fileExtension in org.eclipse.jdt.junit/plugin.xml.
The schema documentation now says:
The fileExtension element is deprecated [.. element syntax ..] This element is no longer used. Instead, use the org.eclipse.debug.ui.launchShortcuts extension point.
If it's not used any more, then that's a breaking change, right? If that happened after 3.0, then you should probably add it to the migration guide.
Darin, what say you re comment 6?

I think the change happened between 1.0 and 2.0. So, I'm not sure that we've broken anyone. We'll have to look back to be sure. We used to use file extensions with the "launch wizard" that existed before launch configurations/shortcuts when debug got rid of its experimental APIs.
We can update a migration guide... but the entry might just be alarming, as it's not a change in 3.3 - it was a change in 2.0.
ancient history. forget it.
> ancient history. forget it. Yep, that's why I said "If that happened after 3.0"; the oldest migration guide we ship is 3.0 -> 3.1.
